trans-unit.source: All drivers running on 64-bit versions of Windows must be signed before Windows will load them.
trans-unit.target: All drivers running on 64-bit versions of Windows must be signed before Windows will load them.

trans-unit.source: However, driver signing is not required on 32-bit versions of Windows.
trans-unit.target: However, driver signing is not required on 32-bit versions of Windows.

trans-unit.source: In order to sign a driver, a certificate is required.
trans-unit.target: In order to sign a driver, a certificate is required.

trans-unit.source: You can create your own certificate to sign your driver with during development and testing.
trans-unit.target: You can create your own certificate to sign your driver with during development and testing.

trans-unit.source: However, for a public release you must sign your driver with a certificate issued by a trusted root authority.
trans-unit.target: However, for a public release you must sign your driver with a certificate issued by a trusted root authority.

trans-unit.source: **Note** A *driver package project* can package the output of other projects.
trans-unit.target: **Note** A *driver package project* can package the output of other projects.

trans-unit.source: If you build a driver package project, Microsoft Visual Studio will build the other projects on which it has dependencies.
trans-unit.target: If you build a driver package project, Microsoft Visual Studio will build the other projects on which it has dependencies.

trans-unit.source: The driver package project has its own driver signing properties that are separate from any other dependent projects, and its driver signing properties apply *only* to the catalog (if any) produced by the driver package project.
trans-unit.target: The driver package project has its own driver signing properties that are separate from any other dependent projects, and its driver signing properties apply *only* to the catalog (if any) produced by the driver package project.

trans-unit.source: That is, the driver package project will not automatically add an embedded signature to driver binaries produced by other projects, as a different certificate may be used to sign the other driver projects, for example, a test certificate, and the result in such a case would be a driver package where the binaries are unintentionally signed with one certificate, while the package catalog is signed with a different certificate.
trans-unit.target: That is, the driver package project will not automatically add an embedded signature to driver binaries produced by other projects, as a different certificate may be used to sign the other driver projects, for example, a test certificate, and the result in such a case would be a driver package where the binaries are unintentionally signed with one certificate, while the package catalog is signed with a different certificate.

trans-unit.source: This can result in performance degradation.
trans-unit.target: This can result in performance degradation.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a boot start driver binary's embedded signature is invalid, Windows cannot use certificate it was signed with to validate the binary.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a boot start driver binary's embedded signature is invalid, Windows cannot use certificate it was signed with to validate the binary.

trans-unit.source: Instead, Windows must validate the binary against the catalog's signature, which would increase boot time.
trans-unit.target: Instead, Windows must validate the binary against the catalog's signature, which would increase boot time.

trans-unit.source: This section describes how to use Visual Studio to sign a driver package.
trans-unit.target: This section describes how to use Visual Studio to sign a driver package.

trans-unit.source: Signing a Driver During Development and Testing
trans-unit.target: Signing a Driver During Development and Testing

trans-unit.source: Signing a Driver for Public Release
trans-unit.target: Signing a Driver for Public Release
